provenance:
Mme. Devisme (nèe Pigalle), Paris, France by 1888; (Devisme sale through Chevallier, Paris, France, March 17, 1888, lot 37); Camille Groult, Paris, France; by descent to Jean Groult, Paris, France; [1] (Wildenstein and Co., Inc., New York, New York); purchased by the MIA in 1952.

[1] Letter in curatorial file from Georges Wildenstein dated October 30 1952: "As you know, this famous picture was one of the gems of the renowned collection of Camille Groult in Paris…..All my life, I had hoped to own this painting, although I never thought it would be for sale. It took the most unusual circumstances, in particular the death of my old friend Jean Groult, for this picture to leave his famous mansion on Avenue Malakoff."
The Groult auction was held in Paris on March 21, 1952.
text:
This picture may appear to reproduce the casual clutter of an 18th-century tabletop. Not so. Chardin carefully selected objects to convey specific meanings. A palette with brushes, placed atop a paint box, symbolizes the art of painting. Building plans, spread beneath drafting and surveying tools, represent architecture. An ornate bronze pitcher alludes to goldsmithing, and the red portfolio symbolizes drawing. The plaster model of J. B. Pigalle's Mercury, an actual work by a friend of Chardin's, stands for sculpture.

The cross on a ribbon is the Order of Saint Michael, the highest honor an artist could then receive. Pigalle was the first sculptor to win it. So this painting sends multiple messages: it presents emblems of the arts and of artists' glory and honors a specific artist, Pigalle.
A still life (or painting of objects), which is composed from scratch by its creator, can be used to convey complex meanings.
title: The Attributes of the Arts and the Rewards Which Are Accorded Them
